title: Introduction
description: Brian Holt introduces you to himself, the Complete Intro to React version 6, and what you can expect to learn

title: Pure React
description: Brian teaches React without any frills: just you, some JavaScript, and the browser. No build step.

title: Components
description: Brian teaches React without any frills: just you, some JavaScript, and the browser. No build step.

title: npm
description: When putting any sort of JavaScript project together, npm is an essential tool. Brian talks about how to get started with npm.

title: Prettier
description: Brian talks about his favorite JS tool, Prettier, a tool that that helps you maintain consistent code style with no work on the dev's part.

title: ESLint
description: An essential part of maintaining a project a long time is discipline in coding standards and avoiding antipatterns. ESLint is a great tool that helps you do just that.

title: Git
description: Git is a critical part of any JS project and Brian makes sure you have it set up.

title: Parcel
description: Setting up a build process has historically been a big barrier to entry for most developers. Brian shows you how to set up Parcel which makes the whole process a breeze.

title: Babel
description: Typically Parcel handles all of your Babel needs out-of-the-box but the pet app project needs one specific transformation. Brian demonstrates how to set up a new Babel configuration.

title: Browserlist
description: Babel transforms your JS code from futuristic code to code that is understandable by older browsers. Via a package called browserslist (which Parcel installed for you) you can Babel what browsers to target.

title: JSX
description: JSX is an essential part of writing React. Brian teaches you to leverage your newfound React knowledge and make it much easier to read with JSX

title: Hooks
description: React manages view state through a mechanism called hooks. Brian teaches you how to use them as you build components.

title: useEffect
description: useEffect is a criticl hook for React, allowing developers to do asynchronous actions like making HTTP requests

title: Custom Hooks
description: You can even make your own hooks! Brian shows how to extract logic out of a component to share a hook across components!

title: Handling User Input
description: Brian shows how to wire up your app to work with users interacting with the site.

title: Component Composition
description: One component should do one thing. Brian shows you how to break down bigger components into smaller components.

title: React Dev Tools
description: An essential tool in any React developer's toolbox is the official React Dev Tools extension. Brian shows you how to install and use them.

title: React Router
description: One component should do one thing. Brian shows you how to break down bigger components into smaller components.

title: Class Components
description: While many components are written with hooks, the older API of class-based components are still around and still useful. Brian shows you when and how to use the class components API.

title: Class Properties
description: Using constructors to set initial state for class components is verbose and can be done better. Brian teaches you to use the new feature in JavaScript, class properties, to make your code easy to read.

title: Managing State in Class Components
description: Class components work a little different from hooks in terms of marshalling state. Brian teaches you how to manage your state using setState and life cycle methods.

title: Conclusion of Complete Intro to React
description: A quick note and congratulations from Brian for completing the Complete Intro to React v6!

title: Ways to Expand on this Project
description: If you want to improve this app and have some more practice with React, here are some ideas for you!

title: Welcome
description: Brian introduces you to Intermediate React v3 and explains how the course is structured.

title: useMemo
description: useMemo memoizes expensive function calls so they only are re-evaluated when needed.

title: useCallback
description: useCallback is quite similar and indeed it's implemented with the same mechanisms as useMemo except it's a callback instead of a value

title: ThemeContext
description: Brian quickly converts ThemeContext.tsx

title: Details
description: Brian quickly converts Details.tsx

title: ErrorBoundary
description: Brian quickly converts ErrorBoundary.tsx

description: Brian quickly converts Carousel.tsx
